column4: HI all!  I'm planning on making a new computer, heavy on virtualization capability.  Any recommendations for a good linux compatible motherboard
X58 or P55 chipset
Was that a question or a statement?
a recommendation
Okay, I'll keep that in mind.
what type of cpu will you be using
I was thinking of maybe a quad core?
yes of course but which family of cpus? you'll need socket 1366 for an X58 board or socket 1156 for a P55

When I last built a machine, the cpu choices were either Pentium 3, or AMD.  Today there is such a bewildering array of choices for CPUs and motherboards, that I don't really have a clue where to start.
oh wow, then you might want to do a bit of reading in order to make sure everything works together (or just ask me and i'll tell you)
I have a historical leaning towards Intel, but I've heard AMD is better and cheaper.
i'm an intel guy
I've heard Asus makes good linux compatible motherboards, but that they've been slipping lately.
i like asus motherboards, haven't had any trouble with linux on them. it's really just the chipset that you need to check if it's compatible with linux (sound, NIC, etc)
So... do you recommend picking a chipset, then finding a motherboard that uses that chipset and then seeing which cpus it can take, or starting with the CPU and then motherboard?
if you want to do heavy stuff like running multiple virtual machines, i would get either a core i5 or core i7 cpu with a P55 motherboard
it depends on how much power you need and how much cash you got
I'm planning on setting up some virtual networks and machines for CCNA and MCSE study purposes.
then yeah, i5 or i7 depending on your money
okay.
money won't likely be an issue.  However, the more expensive, the longer it will take before I scrape the funds together.
